FOOLED

A strong Duke aggregation defeated Hopkins last week. Welch,
Duke's number one singles player,
who ranks with the best of the
South, showed the onlookers a particularly fine brand of tennis. He
defeated Palitz 6-2, 6-3, in a match
that brought forth some sparkling
strokes. Of more interest to the
spectators was the number one doubles match between Griffin and
Welch, of Duke, and Palitz and
Brooke, of Hopkins. After dividing the first two sets, the visiting
team came from behind to win the
final set, 9-7.

Tau Beta Pi Elects
Kaufman President
As a result of an election held
Monday, May 1, Richard Kaufman,
a junior in the school of electrical
engineering, was elected president
of Tau Beta Pi, national honorary
engineering fraternity, for 1933-34.
Philip Onderdonk, a new plan student in the department of chemistry
was chosen as vice-president.
John Terry was chosen corresponding secretary; Henry Orth as
recording secretary; Paul Levin,
treasurer; William Small, cataloguer; and Raymond Flack, assistant catologuer.

Entries in the Pi Delta Epsilon
high school newspaper contest
were forwarded to the judges
yesterday, Hyman Levin, president of the Johns Hopkins chapter of the national honorary journalistic fraternity, announced.
The men who will judge the
papers submitted by Maryland
and District of Columbia high
schools having such publications
are William S. Maulsby, head of
the journalism department of the

(1

University of Pittsburgh; Philip
M. Wagner, of The Evening Sun
editorial staff; and Harvey Rivkin,
staff correspondent for the International News Service. The
judges will submit their decisions
by May 24. The entries are to be
judged on the basis of news content, editorial content, and makeup.

students make the Shelton their New
York home than at any club or
other hotel. One reason for this is
the free recreational features plus a.
desire on the part of Shelton employees. Room rates have been

month upward. A room from $2.50
daily.

at reasonable prices.

Speaker At First Session

A prominent newspaper man will
talk at the opening general business
session, November 17, at which
Dean Berry will probably present
the address of welcome to the delegates from the 26 papers in the I.
N. A. In the evening the editors
and business managers will hold
separate meetings at which papers
by several delegates will be read and
discussed. Harvey Rivkin, staff correspondent of the International
News Service, will address the editors at their session.
Following the group meetings, an
informal dance, which will be open
to the public and which will be sponsored by THE NEWS-LETTER, will
be held in Levering Hall, 10 P. M.
to 1 A. M.

MULDAUER TO ADDRESS
ENGINEERING SOCIETIES
On Wednesday, May 17th, at
4:15 p. m., in M. E. 110, Mr. G. B.
Muldauer, general agent for the
National Board of Fire Underwriters' Laboratories, will speak before
a joint meeting of the Electrical
Club and the Hopkins chapter of the
American Society of Mechanical
Engineers.
The Johns Hopkins Electrical
Club, composed of all the Junior
and Senior Electrical Engineers,
holds its meetings every week and
it functions entirely without faculty
intervention.

LL, it's like this. Back in the old
days, when men wore high hats and
frock coats, they had plenty of time to
think things out, and they had sense, too.
They used to sit down on a log and take
the time to whittle their tobacco from a
plug, to be sure of having a cool smoke.

WE

In those days,a man named Wellman,
right here in Quincy,Ill., made about the
best tobacco you could get. He knew how
to keep the flavor fine and mellow.
Well, sir, the people who make this
Granger Rough Cut acquired Mr.
Wellman's method, and they must have
•known how the old boys used to whittle
their tobacco to make it smoke cool. Yes,
sir, this Granger is the real stuff. The
same mellowness and fine flavor that
Wellman used to hand out to his friends.
And it's whittled into big shaggy flakes
all ready for the pipe.'Rough Cut' they
call it--ecut rough to smoke cool' is the
best way I can describe it.

Now we wanted to sell Granger for 100.

the package. We give smokers this good

pouch for 100.

long, but it has grown to be a popular
smoke. And there is this much about it—

to smoke it, who didn't keep on. Folks
seem to like it.

medley relay team and hope to capture the event. Negotiations are

Catholic University on May 20.

FOOLED

A strong Duke aggregation defeated Hopkins last week. Welch,
Duke's number one singles player,
who ranks with the best of the
South, showed the onlookers a particularly fine brand of tennis. He
defeated Palitz 6-2, 6-3, in a match
that brought forth some sparkling
strokes. Of more interest to the
spectators was the number one doubles match between Griffin and
Welch, of Duke, and Palitz and
Brooke, of Hopkins. After dividing the first two sets, the visiting
team came from behind to win the
final set, 9-7.

Tau Beta Pi Elects
Kaufman President
As a result of an election held
Monday, May 1, Richard Kaufman,
a junior in the school of electrical
engineering, was elected president
of Tau Beta Pi, national honorary
engineering fraternity, for 1933-34.
Philip Onderdonk, a new plan student in the department of chemistry
was chosen as vice-president.
John Terry was chosen corresponding secretary; Henry Orth as
recording secretary; Paul Levin,
treasurer; William Small, cataloguer; and Raymond Flack, assistant catologuer.

Entries in the Pi Delta Epsilon
high school newspaper contest
were forwarded to the judges
yesterday, Hyman Levin, president of the Johns Hopkins chapter of the national honorary journalistic fraternity, announced.
The men who will judge the
papers submitted by Maryland
and District of Columbia high
schools having such publications
are William S. Maulsby, head of
the journalism department of the

(1

University of Pittsburgh; Philip
M. Wagner, of The Evening Sun
editorial staff; and Harvey Rivkin,
staff correspondent for the International News Service. The
judges will submit their decisions
by May 24. The entries are to be
judged on the basis of news content, editorial content, and makeup.

students make the Shelton their New
York home than at any club or
other hotel. One reason for this is
the free recreational features plus a.
desire on the part of Shelton employees. Room rates have been

month upward. A room from $2.50

Speaker At First Session

A prominent newspaper man will
talk at the opening general business
session, November 17, at which
Dean Berry will probably present
the address of welcome to the delegates from the 26 papers in the I.
N. A. In the evening the editors
and business managers will hold
separate meetings at which papers
by several delegates will be read and
discussed. Harvey Rivkin, staff correspondent of the International
News Service, will address the editors at their session.
Following the group meetings, an
informal dance, which will be open
to the public and which will be sponsored by THE NEWS-LETTER, will
be held in Levering Hall, 10 P. M.
to 1 A. M.

MULDAUER TO ADDRESS
ENGINEERING SOCIETIES
On Wednesday, May 17th, at
4:15 p. m., in M. E. 110, Mr. G. B.
Muldauer, general agent for the
National Board of Fire Underwriters' Laboratories, will speak before
a joint meeting of the Electrical
Club and the Hopkins chapter of the
American Society of Mechanical
Engineers.
The Johns Hopkins Electrical
Club, composed of all the Junior
and Senior Electrical Engineers,
holds its meetings every week and
it functions entirely without faculty
intervention.

Well, sir, the people who make this

•known how the old boys used to whittle

Now we wanted to sell Granger for 100.
It was just a question of how to do it for
the price. So we pack Granger in a sensible foil pouch instead of an expensive
package, knowing that a man can't smoke
the package. We give smokers this good
